This may be useful when listening to hover, click and selection events. Note that, *scatter* traces also appends customdata items in the markers DOM elements data any info calc Array containing integer indices of selected points. Has an effect only for traces that support selections. Note that an empty array means an empty selection where the `unselected` are turned on for all points, whereas, any other non-array values means no selection all where the `selected` and `unselected` styles have no effect. color style TRUE none Sets the background color of the hover labels for this trace color style TRUE none Sets the border color of the hover labels for this trace. string style TRUE TRUE none HTML font family - the typeface that will be applied by the web browser. The web browser will only be able to apply a font if it is available on the system which it operates. Provide multiple font families, separated by commas, to indicate the preference in which to apply fonts if they aren't available on the system. The plotly service (at https://plot.ly or on-premise) generates images on a server, where only a select number of fonts are installed and supported. These include *Arial*, *Balto*, *Courier New*, *Droid Sans*,, *Droid Serif*, *Droid Sans Mono*, *Gravitas One*, *Old Standard TT*, *Open Sans*, *Overpass*, *PT Sans Narrow*, *Raleway*, *Times New Roman*. TRUE number style 1 none TRUE color style none TRUE none Sets the font used in hover labels. object string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for family . none string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for size . none string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for color . none integer -1 TRUE style none Sets the length (in number of characters) of the trace name in the hover labels for this trace. -1 shows the whole name regardless of length. 0-3 shows the first 0-3 characters, and an integer >3 will show the whole name if it is less than that many characters, but if it is longer, will truncate to `namelength - 3` characters and add an ellipsis. calc object string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for bgcolor . none string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for bordercolor . none string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for namelength . none string TRUE TRUE info calc The stream id number links a data trace on a plot with a stream. See https://plot.ly/settings for more details. number 0 10000 500 info calc Sets the maximum number of points to keep on the plots from an incoming stream. If `maxpoints` is set to *50*, only the newest 50 points will be displayed on the plot. calc object calc An array of operations that manipulate the trace data, for example filtering or sorting the data arrays. object object any info none Controls persistence of some user-driven changes to the trace: `constraintrange` in `parcoords` traces, as well as some `editable: true` modifications such as `name` and `colorbar.title`. Defaults to `layout.uirevision`. Note that other user-driven trace attribute changes are controlled by `layout` attributes: `trace.visible` is controlled by `layout.legend.uirevision`, `selectedpoints` is controlled by `layout.selectionrevision`, and `colorbar.(x|y)` (accessible with `config: {editable: true}`) is controlled by `layout.editrevision`. Trace changes are tracked by `uid`, which only falls back on trace index if no `uid` is provided. So if your app can add/remove traces before the end of the `data` array, such that the same trace has a different index, you can still preserve user-driven changes if you give each trace a `uid` that stays with it as it moves. data_array calc+clearAxisTypes Sets the radial coordinates data data_array calc+clearAxisTypes Sets the angular coordinates data any 0 info calc+clearAxisTypes Alternate to `r`. Builds a linear space of r coordinates. Use with `dr` where `r0` is the starting coordinate and `dr` the step. number 1 info calc Sets the r coordinate step. any 0 info calc+clearAxisTypes Alternate to `theta`. Builds a linear space of theta coordinates. Use with `dtheta` where `theta0` is the starting coordinate and `dtheta` the step. number info calc Sets the theta coordinate step. By default, the `dtheta` step equals the subplot's period divided by the length of the `r` coordinates. enumerated radians degrees info calc+clearAxisTypes Sets the unit of input *theta* values. Has an effect only when on *linear* angular axes. any TRUE info calc Sets where the bar base is drawn (in radial axis units). In *stack* barmode, traces that set *base* will be excluded and drawn in *overlay* mode instead. number TRUE info calc Shifts the angular position where the bar is drawn (in *thetatunit* units). number 0 TRUE info calc Sets the bar angular width (in *thetaunit* units). string info TRUE calc Sets hover text elements associated with each bar. If a single string, the same string appears over all bars. If an array of string, the items are mapped in order to the this trace's coordinates. string info TRUE style Same as `text`. number 0 TRUE style style TRUE Sets the width (in px) of the lines bounding the marker points. 0 calc color TRUE style style Sets themarker.linecolor. It accepts either a specific color or an array of numbers that are mapped to the colorscale relative to the max and min values of the array or relative to `marker.line.cmin` and `marker.line.cmax` if set. boolean info TRUE calc Determines whether or not the color domain is computed with respect to the input data (here in `marker.line.color`) or the bounds set in `marker.line.cmin` and `marker.line.cmax` Has an effect only if in `marker.line.color`is set to a numerical array. Defaults to `false` when `marker.line.cmin` and `marker.line.cmax` are set by the user. number info plot FALSE Sets the lower bound of the color domain. Has an effect only if in `marker.line.color`is set to a numerical array. Value should have the same units as in `marker.line.color` and if set, `marker.line.cmax` must be set as well. number info plot FALSE Sets the upper bound of the color domain. Has an effect only if in `marker.line.color`is set to a numerical array. Value should have the same units as in `marker.line.color` and if set, `marker.line.cmin` must be set as well. number info calc Sets the mid-point of the color domain by scaling `marker.line.cmin` and/or `marker.line.cmax` to be equidistant to this point. Has an effect only if in `marker.line.color`is set to a numerical array. Value should have the same units as in `marker.line.color`. Has no effect when `marker.line.cauto` is `false`. colorscale style calc FALSE Sets the colorscale. Has an effect only if in `marker.line.color`is set to a numerical array. The colorscale must be an array containing arrays mapping a normalized value to an rgb, rgba, hex, hsl, hsv, or named color string. At minimum, a mapping for the lowest (0) and highest (1) values are required. For example, `[[0, 'rgb(0,0,255)', [1, 'rgb(255,0,0)']]`. To control the bounds of the colorscale in color space, use`marker.line.cmin` and `marker.line.cmax`. Alternatively, `colorscale` may be a palette name string of the following list: Greys,YlGnBu,Greens,YlOrRd,Bluered,RdBu,Reds,Blues,Picnic,Rainbow,Portland,Jet,Hot,Blackbody,Earth,Electric,Viridis,Cividis. boolean style TRUE calc Determines whether the colorscale is a default palette (`autocolorscale: true`) or the palette determined by `marker.line.colorscale`. Has an effect only if in `marker.line.color`is set to a numerical array. In case `colorscale` is unspecified or `autocolorscale` is true, the default palette will be chosen according to whether numbers in the `color` array are all positive, all negative or mixed. boolean style FALSE plot Reverses the color mapping if true. Has an effect only if in `marker.line.color`is set to a numerical array. If true, `marker.line.cmin` will correspond to the last color in the array and `marker.line.cmax` will correspond to the first color. object string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for width . none string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for color . none calc color TRUE style style Sets themarkercolor. It accepts either a specific color or an array of numbers that are mapped to the colorscale relative to the max and min values of the array or relative to `marker.cmin` and `marker.cmax` if set. boolean info TRUE calc Determines whether or not the color domain is computed with respect to the input data (here in `marker.color`) or the bounds set in `marker.cmin` and `marker.cmax` Has an effect only if in `marker.color`is set to a numerical array. Defaults to `false` when `marker.cmin` and `marker.cmax` are set by the user. number info plot FALSE Sets the lower bound of the color domain. Has an effect only if in `marker.color`is set to a numerical array. Value should have the same units as in `marker.color` and if set, `marker.cmax` must be set as well. number info plot FALSE Sets the upper bound of the color domain. Has an effect only if in `marker.color`is set to a numerical array. Value should have the same units as in `marker.color` and if set, `marker.cmin` must be set as well. number info calc Sets the mid-point of the color domain by scaling `marker.cmin` and/or `marker.cmax` to be equidistant to this point. Has an effect only if in `marker.color`is set to a numerical array. Value should have the same units as in `marker.color`. Has no effect when `marker.cauto` is `false`. colorscale style calc FALSE Sets the colorscale. Has an effect only if in `marker.color`is set to a numerical array. The colorscale must be an array containing arrays mapping a normalized value to an rgb, rgba, hex, hsl, hsv, or named color string. At minimum, a mapping for the lowest (0) and highest (1) values are required. For example, `[[0, 'rgb(0,0,255)', [1, 'rgb(255,0,0)']]`. To control the bounds of the colorscale in color space, use`marker.cmin` and `marker.cmax`. Alternatively, `colorscale` may be a palette name string of the following list: Greys,YlGnBu,Greens,YlOrRd,Bluered,RdBu,Reds,Blues,Picnic,Rainbow,Portland,Jet,Hot,Blackbody,Earth,Electric,Viridis,Cividis. boolean style TRUE calc Determines whether the colorscale is a default palette (`autocolorscale: true`) or the palette determined by `marker.colorscale`. Has an effect only if in `marker.color`is set to a numerical array. In case `colorscale` is unspecified or `autocolorscale` is true, the default palette will be chosen according to whether numbers in the `color` array are all positive, all negative or mixed. boolean style FALSE plot Reverses the color mapping if true. Has an effect only if in `marker.color`is set to a numerical array. If true, `marker.cmin` will correspond to the last color in the array and `marker.cmax` will correspond to the first color. boolean info FALSE calc Determines whether or not a colorbar is displayed for this trace. Has an effect only if in `marker.color`is set to a numerical array. enumerated fraction style pixels Determines whether this color bar's thickness (i.e. the measure in the constant color direction) is set in units of plot *fraction* or in *pixels*. Use `thickness` to set the value. colorbars number style 0 30 Sets the thickness of the color bar This measure excludes the size of the padding, ticks and labels. colorbars enumerated fraction info fraction Determines whether this color bar's length (i.e. the measure in the color variation direction) is set in units of plot *fraction* or in *pixels. Use `len` to set the value. colorbars number 0 1 style Sets the length of the color bar This measure excludes the padding of both ends. That is, the color bar length is this length minus the padding on both ends. colorbars number 1.02 -2 3 style Sets the x position of the color bar (in plot fraction). colorbars enumerated left left style Sets this color bar's horizontal position anchor. This anchor binds the `x` position to the *left*, *center* or *right* of the color bar. colorbars number style 0 10 Sets the amount of padding (in px) along the x direction. colorbars number style 0.5 -2 3 Sets the y position of the color bar (in plot fraction). colorbars enumerated top style middle Sets this color bar's vertical position anchor This anchor binds the `y` position to the *top*, *middle* or *bottom* of the color bar. colorbars number style 0 10 Sets the amount of padding (in px) along the y direction. colorbars color #444 style colorbars Sets the axis line color. number 0 1 style colorbars Sets the width (in px) of the axis line. color #444 style colorbars Sets the axis line color. number style 0 0 Sets the width (in px) or the border enclosing this color bar. colorbars color style rgba(0,0,0,0) Sets the color of padded area. colorbars enumerated auto info colorbars Sets the tick mode for this axis. If *auto*, the number of ticks is set via `nticks`. If *linear*, the placement of the ticks is determined by a starting position `tick0` and a tick step `dtick` (*linear* is the default value if `tick0` and `dtick` are provided). If *array*, the placement of the ticks is set via `tickvals` and the tick text is `ticktext`. (*array* is the default value if `tickvals` is provided). integer 0 0 style colorbars Specifies the maximum number of ticks for the particular axis. The actual number of ticks will be chosen automatically to be less than or equal to `nticks`. Has an effect only if `tickmode` is set to *auto*. any style colorbars linear Sets the placement of the first tick on this axis. Use with `dtick`. If the axis `type` is *log*, then you must take the log of your starting tick (e.g. to set the starting tick to 100, set the `tick0` to 2) except when `dtick`=*L<f>* (see `dtick` for more info). If the axis `type` is *date*, it should be a date string, like date data. If the axis `type` is *category*, it should be a number, using the scale where each category is assigned a serial number from zero in the order it appears. any style colorbars linear Sets the step in-between ticks on this axis. Use with `tick0`. Must be a positive number, or special strings available to *log* and *date* axes. If the axis `type` is *log*, then ticks are set every 10^(n*dtick) where n is the tick number. For example, to set a tick mark at 1, 10, 100, 1000, ... set dtick to 1. To set tick marks at 1, 100, 10000, ... set dtick to 2. To set tick marks at 1, 5, 25, 125, 625, 3125, ... set dtick to log_10(5), or 0.69897000433. *log* has several special values; *L<f>*, where `f` is a positive number, gives ticks linearly spaced in value (but not position). For example `tick0` = 0.1, `dtick` = *L0.5* will put ticks at 0.1, 0.6, 1.1, 1.6 etc. To show powers of 10 plus small digits between, use *D1* (all digits) or *D2* (only 2 and 5). `tick0` is ignored for *D1* and *D2*. If the axis `type` is *date*, then you must convert the time to milliseconds. For example, to set the interval between ticks to one day, set `dtick` to 86400000.0. *date* also has special values *M<n>* gives ticks spaced by a number of months. `n` must be a positive integer. To set ticks on the 15th of every third month, set `tick0` to *2000-01-15* and `dtick` to *M3*. To set ticks every 4 years, set `dtick` to *M48* data_array colorbars Sets the values at which ticks on this axis appear. Only has an effect if `tickmode` is set to *array*. Used with `ticktext`. data data_array colorbars Sets the text displayed at the ticks position via `tickvals`. Only has an effect if `tickmode` is set to *array*. Used with `tickvals`. data enumerated outside style colorbars Determines whether ticks are drawn or not. If **, this axis' ticks are not drawn. If *outside* (*inside*), this axis' are drawn outside (inside) the axis lines. number 0 5 style colorbars Sets the tick length (in px). number 0 1 style colorbars Sets the tick width (in px). color #444 style colorbars Sets the tick color. boolean TRUE style colorbars Determines whether or not the tick labels are drawn. string style TRUE TRUE HTML font family - the typeface that will be applied by the web browser. The web browser will only be able to apply a font if it is available on the system which it operates. Provide multiple font families, separated by commas, to indicate the preference in which to apply fonts if they aren't available on the system. The plotly service (at https://plot.ly or on-premise) generates images on a server, where only a select number of fonts are installed and supported. These include *Arial*, *Balto*, *Courier New*, *Droid Sans*,, *Droid Serif*, *Droid Sans Mono*, *Gravitas One*, *Old Standard TT*, *Open Sans*, *Overpass*, *PT Sans Narrow*, *Raleway*, *Times New Roman*. colorbars number style 1 colorbars color style colorbars Sets the color bar's tick label font colorbars object angle auto style colorbars Sets the angle of the tick labels with respect to the horizontal. For example, a `tickangle` of -90 draws the tick labels vertically. string style colorbars Sets the tick label formatting rule using d3 formatting mini-languages which are very similar to those in Python. For numbers, see: https://github.com/d3/d3-format/blob/master/README.md#locale_format And for dates see: https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format/blob/master/README.md#locale_format We add one item to d3's date formatter: *%{n}f* for fractional seconds with n digits. For example, *2016-10-13 09:15:23.456* with tickformat *%H~%M~%S.%2f* would display *09~15~23.46* boolean info TRUE colorbars Determines whether or not this stop is used. If `false`, this stop is ignored even within its `dtickrange`. info_array info any colorbars colorbars range [*min*, *max*], where *min*, *max* - dtick values which describe some zoom level, it is possible to omit *min* or *max* value by passing *null* string style colorbars string - dtickformat for described zoom level, the same as *tickformat* colorbars string style colorbars When used in a template, named items are created in the output figure in addition to any items the figure already has in this array. You can modify these items in the output figure by making your own item with `templateitemname` matching this `name` alongside your modifications (including `visible: false` or `enabled: false` to hide it). Has no effect outside of a template. string info colorbars Used to refer to a named item in this array in the template. Named items from the template will be created even without a matching item in the input figure, but you can modify one by making an item with `templateitemname` matching its `name`, alongside your modifications (including `visible: false` or `enabled: false` to hide it). If there is no template or no matching item, this item will be hidden unless you explicitly show it with `visible: true`. object object string style colorbars Sets a tick label prefix. enumerated all all style colorbars If *all*, all tick labels are displayed with a prefix. If *first*, only the first tick is displayed with a prefix. If *last*, only the last tick is displayed with a suffix. If *none*, tick prefixes are hidden. string style colorbars Sets a tick label suffix. enumerated all all style colorbars Same as `showtickprefix` but for tick suffixes. boolean FALSE style colorbars If "true", even 4-digit integers are separated enumerated none B style colorbars Determines a formatting rule for the tick exponents. For example, consider the number 1,000,000,000. If *none*, it appears as 1,000,000,000. If *e*, 1e+9. If *E*, 1E+9. If *power*, 1x10^9 (with 9 in a super script). If *SI*, 1G. If *B*, 1B. enumerated all all style colorbars If *all*, all exponents are shown besides their significands. If *first*, only the exponent of the first tick is shown. If *last*, only the exponent of the last tick is shown. If *none*, no exponents appear. string info Sets the title of the color bar. Note that before the existence of `title.text`, the title's contents used to be defined as the `title` attribute itself. This behavior has been deprecated. colorbars string style TRUE TRUE HTML font family - the typeface that will be applied by the web browser. The web browser will only be able to apply a font if it is available on the system which it operates. Provide multiple font families, separated by commas, to indicate the preference in which to apply fonts if they aren't available on the system. The plotly service (at https://plot.ly or on-premise) generates images on a server, where only a select number of fonts are installed and supported. These include *Arial*, *Balto*, *Courier New*, *Droid Sans*,, *Droid Serif*, *Droid Sans Mono*, *Gravitas One*, *Old Standard TT*, *Open Sans*, *Overpass*, *PT Sans Narrow*, *Raleway*, *Times New Roman*. colorbars number style 1 colorbars color style colorbars Sets this color bar's title font. Note that the title's font used to be set by the now deprecated `titlefont` attribute. colorbars object enumerated right style top Determines the location of color bar's title with respect to the color bar. Note that the title's location used to be set by the now deprecated `titleside` attribute. colorbars colorbars object string info Deprecated in favor of color bar's `title.text`. Note that value of color bar's `title` is no longer a simple *string* but a set of sub-attributes. colorbars string style TRUE TRUE HTML font family - the typeface that will be applied by the web browser. The web browser will only be able to apply a font if it is available on the system which it operates. Provide multiple font families, separated by commas, to indicate the preference in which to apply fonts if they aren't available on the system. The plotly service (at https://plot.ly or on-premise) generates images on a server, where only a select number of fonts are installed and supported. These include *Arial*, *Balto*, *Courier New*, *Droid Sans*,, *Droid Serif*, *Droid Sans Mono*, *Gravitas One*, *Old Standard TT*, *Open Sans*, *Overpass*, *PT Sans Narrow*, *Raleway*, *Times New Roman*. colorbars number style 1 colorbars color style colorbars Deprecated in favor of color bar's `title.font`. colorbars enumerated right style top Deprecated in favor of color bar's `title.side`. colorbars colorbars object string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for tickvals . none string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for ticktext . none number TRUE 1 0 1 style style Sets the opacity of the bars. object string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for color . none string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for opacity . none flaglist info r all TRUE all none Determines which trace information appear on hover. If `none` or `skip` are set, no information is displayed upon hovering. But, if `none` is set, click and hover events are still fired. string info none Template string used for rendering the information that appear on hover box. Note that this will override `hoverinfo`. Variables are inserted using %{variable}, for example "y: %{y}". Numbers are formatted using d3-format's syntax %{variable:d3-format}, for example "Price: %{y:$.2f}". See https://github.com/d3/d3-format/blob/master/README.md#locale_format for details on the formatting syntax. The variables available in `hovertemplate` are the ones emitted as event data described at this link https://plot.ly/javascript/plotlyjs-events/#event-data. Additionally, every attributes that can be specified per-point (the ones that are `arrayOk: true`) are available. Anything contained in tag `<extra>` is displayed in the secondary box, for example "<extra>{fullData.name}</extra>". To hide the secondary box completely, use an empty tag `<extra></extra>`. TRUE number 0 1 style style Sets the marker opacity of selected points. color style style Sets the marker color of selected points. style object color style style Sets the text font color of selected points. style object style object number 0 1 style style Sets the marker opacity of unselected points, applied only when a selection exists. color style style Sets the marker color of unselected points, applied only when a selection exists. style object color style style Sets the text font color of unselected points, applied only when a selection exists. style object style object subplotid info polar calc Sets a reference between this trace's data coordinates and a polar subplot. If *polar* (the default value), the data refer to `layout.polar`. If *polar2*, the data refer to `layout.polar2`, and so on. string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for ids . none string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for customdata . none string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for r . none string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for theta . none string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for base . none string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for offset . none string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for width . none string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for text . none string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for hovertext . none string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for hoverinfo . none string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for hovertemplate . none enumerated stack stack info calc Determines how bars at the same location coordinate are displayed on the graph. With *stack*, the bars are stacked on top of one another With *overlay*, the bars are plotted over one another, you might need to an *opacity* to see multiple bars. number 0.1 0 1 style calc Sets the gap between bars of adjacent location coordinates. Values are unitless, they represent fractions of the minimum difference in bar positions in the data. area enumerated TRUE info TRUE calc Determines whether or not this trace is visible. If *legendonly*, the trace is not drawn, but can appear as a legend item (provided that the legend itself is visible). boolean info TRUE style Determines whether or not an item corresponding to this trace is shown in the legend. string info style Sets the legend group for this trace. Traces part of the same legend group hide/show at the same time when toggling legend items. number style 0 1 1 style Sets the opacity of the trace. string info style Sets the trace name. The trace name appear as the legend item and on hover. string info plot TRUE Assign an id to this trace, Use this to provide object constancy between traces during animations and transitions. data_array calc TRUE Assigns id labels to each datum. These ids for object constancy of data points during animation. Should be an array of strings, not numbers or any other type. data data_array calc Assigns extra data each datum. This may be useful when listening to hover, click and selection events. Note that, *scatter* traces also appends customdata items in the markers DOM elements data any info calc Array containing integer indices of selected points. Has an effect only for traces that support selections. Note that an empty array means an empty selection where the `unselected` are turned on for all points, whereas, any other non-array values means no selection all where the `selected` and `unselected` styles have no effect. flaglist info x all TRUE all none Determines which trace information appear on hover. If `none` or `skip` are set, no information is displayed upon hovering. But, if `none` is set, click and hover events are still fired. color style TRUE none Sets the background color of the hover labels for this trace color style TRUE none Sets the border color of the hover labels for this trace. string style TRUE TRUE none HTML font family - the typeface that will be applied by the web browser. The web browser will only be able to apply a font if it is available on the system which it operates. Provide multiple font families, separated by commas, to indicate the preference in which to apply fonts if they aren't available on the system. The plotly service (at https://plot.ly or on-premise) generates images on a server, where only a select number of fonts are installed and supported. These include *Arial*, *Balto*, *Courier New*, *Droid Sans*,, *Droid Serif*, *Droid Sans Mono*, *Gravitas One*, *Old Standard TT*, *Open Sans*, *Overpass*, *PT Sans Narrow*, *Raleway*, *Times New Roman*. TRUE number style 1 none TRUE color style none TRUE none Sets the font used in hover labels. object string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for family . none string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for size . none string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for color . none integer -1 TRUE style none Sets the length (in number of characters) of the trace name in the hover labels for this trace. -1 shows the whole name regardless of length. 0-3 shows the first 0-3 characters, and an integer >3 will show the whole name if it is less than that many characters, but if it is longer, will truncate to `namelength - 3` characters and add an ellipsis. calc object string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for bgcolor . none string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for bordercolor . none string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for namelength . none string TRUE TRUE info calc The stream id number links a data trace on a plot with a stream. See https://plot.ly/settings for more details. number 0 10000 500 info calc Sets the maximum number of points to keep on the plots from an incoming stream. If `maxpoints` is set to *50*, only the newest 50 points will be displayed on the plot. calc object calc An array of operations that manipulate the trace data, for example filtering or sorting the data arrays. object object any info none Controls persistence of some user-driven changes to the trace: `constraintrange` in `parcoords` traces, as well as some `editable: true` modifications such as `name` and `colorbar.title`. Defaults to `layout.uirevision`. Note that other user-driven trace attribute changes are controlled by `layout` attributes: `trace.visible` is controlled by `layout.legend.uirevision`, `selectedpoints` is controlled by `layout.selectionrevision`, and `colorbar.(x|y)` (accessible with `config: {editable: true}`) is controlled by `layout.editrevision`. Trace changes are tracked by `uid`, which only falls back on trace index if no `uid` is provided. So if your app can add/remove traces before the end of the `data` array, such that the same trace has a different index, you can still preserve user-driven changes if you give each trace a `uid` that stays with it as it moves. data_array calc Area traces are deprecated! Please switch to the *barpolar* trace type. Sets the radial coordinates for legacy polar chart only. data data_array calc Area traces are deprecated! Please switch to the *barpolar* trace type. Sets the angular coordinates for legacy polar chart only. data color TRUE style style Area traces are deprecated! Please switch to the *barpolar* trace type. Sets themarkercolor. It accepts either a specific color or an array of numbers that are mapped to the colorscale relative to the max and min values of the array or relative to `marker.cmin` and `marker.cmax` if set. TRUE number 0 6 TRUE style calc TRUE Area traces are deprecated! Please switch to the *barpolar* trace type. Sets the marker size (in px). enumerated 0 circle TRUE style style Area traces are deprecated! Please switch to the *barpolar* trace type. Sets the marker symbol type. Adding 100 is equivalent to appending *-open* to a symbol name. Adding 200 is equivalent to appending *-dot* to a symbol name. Adding 300 is equivalent to appending *-open-dot* or *dot-open* to a symbol name. number 0 1 TRUE style style TRUE Area traces are deprecated! Please switch to the *barpolar* trace type. Sets the marker opacity. calc object string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for color . none string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for size . none string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for symbol . none string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for opacity . none string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for ids . none string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for customdata . none string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for hoverinfo . none string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for r . none string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for t . none string style TRUE TRUE calc HTML font family - the typeface that will be applied by the web browser. The web browser will only be able to apply a font if it is available on the system which it operates. Provide multiple font families, separated by commas, to indicate the preference in which to apply fonts if they aren't available on the system. The plotly service (at https://plot.ly or on-premise) generates images on a server, where only a select number of fonts are installed and supported. These include *Arial*, *Balto*, *Courier New*, *Droid Sans*,, *Droid Serif*, *Droid Sans Mono*, *Gravitas One*, *Old Standard TT*, *Open Sans*, *Overpass*, *PT Sans Narrow*, *Raleway*, *Times New Roman*. "Open Sans", verdana, arial, sans-serif number style 1 calc 12 color style calc #444 calc Sets the global font. Note that fonts used in traces and other layout components inherit from the global font. object string info layoutstyle Sets the plot's title. Note that before the existence of `title.text`, the title's contents used to be defined as the `title` attribute itself. This behavior has been deprecated. string style TRUE TRUE layoutstyle HTML font family - the typeface that will be applied by the web browser. The web browser will only be able to apply a font if it is available on the system which it operates. Provide multiple font families, separated by commas, to indicate the preference in which to apply fonts if they aren't available on the system. The plotly service (at https://plot.ly or on-premise) generates images on a server, where only a select number of fonts are installed and supported. These include *Arial*, *Balto*, *Courier New*, *Droid Sans*,, *Droid Serif*, *Droid Sans Mono*, *Gravitas One*, *Old Standard TT*, *Open Sans*, *Overpass*, *PT Sans Narrow*, *Raleway*, *Times New Roman*. number style 1 layoutstyle color style layoutstyle layoutstyle Sets the title font. Note that the title's font used to be customized by the now deprecated `titlefont` attribute. object enumerated container container info layoutstyle Sets the container `x` refers to. *container* spans the entire `width` of the plot. *paper* refers to the width of the plotting area only. enumerated container container info layoutstyle Sets the container `y` refers to. *container* spans the entire `height` of the plot. *paper* refers to the height of the plotting area only. number 0 1 0.5 style layoutstyle Sets the x position with respect to `xref` in normalized coordinates from *0* (left) to *1* (right). number 0 1 auto style layoutstyle Sets the y position with respect to `yref` in normalized coordinates from *0* (bottom) to *1* (top). *auto* places the baseline of the title onto the vertical center of the top margin. enumerated auto auto info layoutstyle Sets the title's horizontal alignment with respect to its x position. *left* means that the title starts at x, *right* means that the title ends at x and *center* means that the title's center is at x. *auto* divides `xref` by three and calculates the `xanchor` value automatically based on the value of `x`. enumerated auto auto info layoutstyle Sets the title's vertical alignment with respect to its y position. *top* means that the title's cap line is at y, *bottom* means that the title's baseline is at y and *middle* means that the title's midline is at y. *auto* divides `yref` by three and calculates the `yanchor` value automatically based on the value of `y`. number 0 style layoutstyle The amount of padding (in px) along the top of the component. number 0 style layoutstyle The amount of padding (in px) on the right side of the component. number 0 style layoutstyle The amount of padding (in px) along the bottom of the component. number 0 style layoutstyle The amount of padding (in px) on the left side of the component. layoutstyle Sets the padding of the title. Each padding value only applies when the corresponding `xanchor`/`yanchor` value is set accordingly. E.g. for left padding to take effect, `xanchor` must be set to *left*. The same rule applies if `xanchor`/`yanchor` is determined automatically. Padding is muted if the respective anchor value is *middle*/*center*. object layoutstyle object boolean info FALSE none Determines whether or not a layout width or height that has been left undefined by the user is initialized on each relayout. Note that, regardless of this attribute, an undefined layout width or height is always initialized on the first call to plot. number info 10 700 plot Sets the plot's width (in px). number info 10 450 plot Sets the plot's height (in px). number info 0 80 plot Sets the left margin (in px). number info 0 80 plot Sets the right margin (in px). number info 0 100 plot Sets the top margin (in px). number info 0 80 plot Sets the bottom margin (in px). number info 0 0 plot Sets the amount of padding (in px) between the plotting area and the axis lines boolean info TRUE plot plot object color style #fff plot Sets the color of paper where the graph is drawn. color style #fff layoutstyle Sets the color of plotting area in-between x and y axes. string style plot Sets the decimal and thousand separators. For example, *. * puts a '.' before decimals and a space between thousands. In English locales, dflt is *.,* but other locales may alter this default. boolean info FALSE plot Determines whether or not a text link citing the data source is placed at the bottom-right cored of the figure. Has only an effect only on graphs that have been generated via forked graphs from the plotly service (at https://plot.ly or on-premise). boolean info legend Determines whether or not a legend is drawn. Default is `true` if there is a trace to show and any of these: a) Two or more traces would by default be shown in the legend. b) One pie trace is shown in the legend. c) One trace is explicitly given with `showlegend: true`. colorlist #1f77b4 style calc Sets the default trace colors. calc colorscale 0 style calc Sets the default sequential colorscale for positive values. Note that `autocolorscale` must be true for this attribute to work. colorscale 0 style calc Sets the default sequential colorscale for negative values. Note that `autocolorscale` must be true for this attribute to work. colorscale 0 style calc Sets the default diverging colorscale. Note that `autocolorscale` must be true for this attribute to work. object any info calc If provided, a changed value tells `Plotly.react` that one or more data arrays has changed. This way you can modify arrays in-place rather than making a complete new copy for an incremental change. If NOT provided, `Plotly.react` assumes that data arrays are being treated as immutable, thus any data array with a different identity from its predecessor contains new data. any info none Used to allow user interactions with the plot to persist after `Plotly.react` calls that are unaware of these interactions. If `uirevision` is omitted, or if it is given and it changed from the previous `Plotly.react` call, the exact new figure is used. If `uirevision` is truthy and did NOT change, any attribute that has been affected by user interactions and did not receive a different value in the new figure will keep the interaction value. `layout.uirevision` attribute serves as the default for `uirevision` attributes in various sub-containers. For finer control you can set these sub-attributes directly. For example, if your app separately controls the data on the x and y axes you might set `xaxis.uirevision=*time*` and `yaxis.uirevision=*cost*`. Then if only the y data is changed, you can update `yaxis.uirevision=*quantity*` and the y axis range will reset but the x axis range will retain any user-driven zoom. any info none Controls persistence of user-driven changes in `editable: true` configuration, other than trace names and axis titles. Defaults to `layout.uirevision`. any info none Controls persistence of user-driven changes in selected points from all traces. any info calc Default attributes to be applied to the plot. Templates can be created from existing plots using `Plotly.makeTemplate`, or created manually. They should be objects with format: `{layout: layoutTemplate, data: {[type]: [traceTemplate, ...]}, ...}` `layoutTemplate` and `traceTemplate` are objects matching the attribute structure of `layout` and a data trace. Trace templates are applied cyclically to traces of each type. Container arrays (eg `annotations`) have special handling: An object ending in `defaults` (eg `annotationdefaults`) is applied to each array item. But if an item has a `templateitemname` key we look in the template array for an item with matching `name` and apply that instead. If no matching `name` is found we mark the item invisible. Any named template item not referenced is appended to the end of the array, so you can use this for a watermark annotation or a logo image, for example. To omit one of these items on the plot, make an item with matching `templateitemname` and `visible: false`. enumerated v h info modebar Sets the orientation of the modebar. color style modebar Sets the background color of the modebar. color style modebar Sets the color of the icons in the modebar. color style modebar Sets the color of the active or hovered on icons in the modebar. any info none Controls persistence of user-driven changes related to the modebar, including `hovermode`, `dragmode`, and `showspikes` at both the root level and inside subplots. Defaults to `layout.uirevision`. modebar object data_array plot Assigns extra meta information that can be used in various `text` attributes. Attributes such as the graph, axis and colorbar `title.text`, annotation `text` `trace.name` in legend items, `rangeselector`, `updatemenues` and `sliders` `label` text all support `meta`. One can access `meta` fields using template strings: `%{meta[i]}` where `i` is the index of the `meta` item in question. data number info 0 500 none The duration of the transition, in milliseconds. If equal to zero, updates are synchronous. enumerated cubic-in-out linear info none The easing function used for the transition enumerated layout first layout first info none Determines whether the figure's layout or traces smoothly transitions during updates that make both traces and layout change. Sets transition options used during Plotly.react updates. none object string info layoutstyle Value of `title` is no longer a simple *string* but a set of sub-attributes. To set the contents of the title, please use `title.text` now. string style TRUE TRUE layoutstyle HTML font family - the typeface that will be applied by the web browser. The web browser will only be able to apply a font if it is available on the system which it operates. Provide multiple font families, separated by commas, to indicate the preference in which to apply fonts if they aren't available on the system. The plotly service (at https://plot.ly or on-premise) generates images on a server, where only a select number of fonts are installed and supported. These include *Arial*, *Balto*, *Courier New*, *Droid Sans*,, *Droid Serif*, *Droid Sans Mono*, *Gravitas One*, *Old Standard TT*, *Open Sans*, *Overpass*, *PT Sans Narrow*, *Raleway*, *Times New Roman*. number style 1 layoutstyle color style layoutstyle layoutstyle Former `titlefont` is now the sub-attribute `font` of `title`. To customize title font properties, please use `title.font` now. flaglist info event event plot none Determines the mode of single click interactions. *event* is the default value and emits the `plotly_click` event. In addition this mode emits the `plotly_selected` event in drag modes *lasso* and *select*, but with no event data attached (kept for compatibility reasons). The *select* flag enables selecting single data points via click. This mode also supports persistent selections, meaning that pressing Shift while clicking, adds to / subtracts from an existing selection. *select* with `hovermode`: *x* can be confusing, consider explicitly setting `hovermode`: *closest* when using this feature. Selection events are sent accordingly as long as *event* flag is set as well. When the *event* flag is missing, `plotly_click` and `plotly_selected` events are not fired. enumerated info zoom zoom modebar Determines the mode of drag interactions. *select* and *lasso* apply only to scatter traces with markers or text. *orbit* and *turntable* apply only to 3D scenes. enumerated info x modebar Determines the mode of hover interactions. If `clickmode` includes the *select* flag, `hovermode` defaults to *closest*. If `clickmode` lacks the *select* flag, it defaults to *x* or *y* (depending on the trace's `orientation` value) for plots based on cartesian coordinates. For anything else the default value is *closest*. integer -1 20 info none Sets the default distance (in pixels) to look for data to add hover labels (-1 means no cutoff, 0 means no looking for data). This is only a real distance for hovering on point-like objects, like scatter points. For area-like objects (bars, scatter fills, etc) hovering is on inside the area and off outside, but these objects will not supersede hover on point-like objects in case of conflict. integer -1 20 info none Sets the default distance (in pixels) to look for data to draw spikelines to (-1 means no cutoff, 0 means no looking for data). As with hoverdistance, distance does not apply to area-like objects. In addition, some objects can be hovered on but will not generate spikelines, such as scatter fills. color style none Sets the background color of all hover labels on graph color style none Sets the border color of all hover labels on graph. string style TRUE TRUE none HTML font family - the typeface that will be applied by the web browser. The web browser will only be able to apply a font if it is available on the system which it operates. Provide multiple font families, separated by commas, to indicate the preference in which to apply fonts if they aren't available on the system. The plotly service (at https://plot.ly or on-premise) generates images on a server, where only a select number of fonts are installed and supported. These include *Arial*, *Balto*, *Courier New*, *Droid Sans*,, *Droid Serif*, *Droid Sans Mono*, *Gravitas One*, *Old Standard TT*, *Open Sans*, *Overpass*, *PT Sans Narrow*, *Raleway*, *Times New Roman*. Arial, sans-serif number style 1 none 13 color style none none Sets the default hover label font used by all traces on the graph. object integer -1 15 style none Sets the default length (in number of characters) of the trace name in the hover labels for all traces. -1 shows the whole name regardless of length. 0-3 shows the first 0-3 characters, and an integer >3 will show the whole name if it is less than that many characters, but if it is longer, will truncate to `namelength - 3` characters and add an ellipsis. none object enumerated info h any When "dragmode" is set to "select", this limits the selection of the drag to horizontal, vertical or diagonal. "h" only allows horizontal selection, "v" only vertical, "d" only diagonal and "any" sets no limit. none integer 1 info plot The number of rows in the grid. If you provide a 2D `subplots` array or a `yaxes` array, its length is used as the default. But it's also possible to have a different length, if you want to leave a row at the end for non-cartesian subplots. enumerated top to bottom top to bottom info plot Is the first row the top or the bottom? Note that columns are always enumerated from left to right. integer 1 info plot The number of columns in the grid. If you provide a 2D `subplots` array, the length of its longest row is used as the default. If you give an `xaxes` array, its length is used as the default. But it's also possible to have a different length, if you want to leave a row at the end for non-cartesian subplots. info_array TRUE 2 enumerated /^x([2-9]|[1-9][0-9]+)?y([2-9]|[1-9][0-9]+)?$/ plot info plot Used for freeform grids, where some axes may be shared across subplots but others are not. Each entry should be a cartesian subplot id, like *xy* or *x3y2*, or ** to leave that cell empty. You may reuse x axes within the same column, and y axes within the same row. Non-cartesian subplots and traces that support `domain` can place themselves in this grid separately using the `gridcell` attribute. info_array TRUE enumerated /^x([2-9]|[1-9][0-9]+)?$/ plot info plot Used with `yaxes` when the x and y axes are shared across columns and rows. Each entry should be an x axis id like *x*, *x2*, etc., or ** to not put an x axis in that column. Entries other than ** must be unique. Ignored if `subplots` is present. If missing but `yaxes` is present, will generate consecutive IDs. info_array TRUE enumerated /^y([2-9]|[1-9][0-9]+)?$/ plot info plot Used with `yaxes` when the x and y axes are shared across columns and rows. Each entry should be an y axis id like *y*, *y2*, etc., or ** to not put a y axis in that row. Entries other than ** must be unique. Ignored if `subplots` is present. If missing but `xaxes` is present, will generate consecutive IDs. enumerated independent coupled info plot If no `subplots`, `xaxes`, or `yaxes` are given but we do have `rows` and `columns`, we can generate defaults using consecutive axis IDs, in two ways: *coupled* gives one x axis per column and one y axis per row. *independent* uses a new xy pair for each cell, left-to-right across each row then iterating rows according to `roworder`. number 0 1 info plot Horizontal space between grid cells, expressed as a fraction of the total width available to one cell. Defaults to 0.1 for coupled-axes grids and 0.2 for independent grids. number 0 1 info plot Vertical space between grid cells, expressed as a fraction of the total height available to one cell. Defaults to 0.1 for coupled-axes grids and 0.3 for independent grids. info_array info plot number 0 1 plot 0 Sets the horizontal domain of this grid subplot (in plot fraction). The first and last cells end exactly at the domain edges, with no grout around the edges. info_array info plot number 0 1 plot 0 Sets the vertical domain of this grid subplot (in plot fraction). The first and last cells end exactly at the domain edges, with no grout around the edges. plot object enumerated bottom bottom plot info plot Sets where the x axis labels and titles go. *bottom* means the very bottom of the grid. *bottom plot* is the lowest plot that each x axis is used in. *top* and *top plot* are similar. enumerated left left plot info plot Sets where the y axis labels and titles go. *left* means the very left edge of the grid. *left plot* is the leftmost plot that each y axis is used in. *right* and *right plot* are similar. plot object enumerated gregorian info calc gregorian Sets the default calendar system to use for interpreting and displaying dates throughout the plot. boolean info plot A single toggle to hide the axis while preserving interaction like dragging. Default is true when a cheater plot is present on the axis, otherwise false color #444 style ticks Sets default for all colors associated with this axis all at once: line, font, tick, and grid colors. Grid color is lightened by blending this with the plot background Individual pieces can override this. string info ticks Sets the title of this axis. Note that before the existence of `title.text`, the title's contents used to be defined as the `title` attribute itself. This behavior has been deprecated. string style TRUE TRUE ticks HTML font family - the typeface that will be applied by the web browser. The web browser will only be able to apply a font if it is available on the system which it operates. Provide multiple font families, separated by commas, to indicate the preference in which to apply fonts if they aren't available on the system. The plotly service (at https://plot.ly or on-premise) generates images on a server, where only a select number of fonts are installed and supported. These include *Arial*, *Balto*, *Courier New*, *Droid Sans*,, *Droid Serif*, *Droid Sans Mono*, *Gravitas One*, *Old Standard TT*, *Open Sans*, *Overpass*, *PT Sans Narrow*, *Raleway*, *Times New Roman*. number style 1 ticks color style ticks ticks Sets this axis' title font. Note that the title's font used to be customized by the now deprecated `titlefont` attribute. object ticks object enumerated - - info calc TRUE Sets the axis type. By default, plotly attempts to determined the axis type by looking into the data of the traces that referenced the axis in question. enumerated TRUE TRUE info axrange Determines whether or not the range of this axis is computed in relation to the input data. See `rangemode` for more info. If `range` is provided, then `autorange` is set to *false*. enumerated normal normal info plot If *normal*, the range is computed in relation to the extrema of the input data. If *tozero*`, the range extends to 0, regardless of the input data If *nonnegative*, the range is non-negative, regardless of the input data. Applies only to linear axes. info_array info any axrange FALSE TRUE axrange FALSE TRUE Sets the range of this axis. If the axis `type` is *log*, then you must take the log of your desired range (e.g. to set the range from 1 to 100, set the range from 0 to 2). If the axis `type` is *date*, it should be date strings, like date data, though Date objects and unix milliseconds will be accepted and converted to strings. If the axis `type` is *category*, it should be numbers, using the scale where each category is assigned a serial number from zero in the order it appears. boolean FALSE info calc Determines whether or not this axis is zoom-able. If true, then zoom is disabled. enumerated /^x([2-9]|[1-9][0-9]+)?$/ info plot If set to another axis id (e.g. `x2`, `y`), the range of this axis changes together with the range of the corresponding axis such that the scale of pixels per unit is in a constant ratio. Both axes are still zoomable, but when you zoom one, the other will zoom the same amount, keeping a fixed midpoint. `constrain` and `constraintoward` determine how we enforce the constraint. You can chain these, ie `yaxis: {scaleanchor: *x*}, xaxis2: {scaleanchor: *y*}` but you can only link axes of the same `type`. The linked axis can have the opposite letter (to constrain the aspect ratio) or the same letter (to match scales across subplots). Loops (`yaxis: {scaleanchor: *x*}, xaxis: {scaleanchor: *y*}` or longer) are redundant and the last constraint encountered will be ignored to avoid possible inconsistent constraints via `scaleratio`. Note that setting axes simultaneously in both a `scaleanchor` and a `matches` constraint is currently forbidden. number 0 1 info plot If this axis is linked to another by `scaleanchor`, this determines the pixel to unit scale ratio. For example, if this value is 10, then every unit on this axis spans 10 times the number of pixels as a unit on the linked axis. Use this for example to create an elevation profile where the vertical scale is exaggerated a fixed amount with respect to the horizontal. enumerated range range info plot If this axis needs to be compressed (either due to its own `scaleanchor` and `scaleratio` or those of the other axis), determines how that happens: by increasing the *range* (default), or by decreasing the *domain*. enumerated left info plot If this axis needs to be compressed (either due to its own `scaleanchor` and `scaleratio` or those of the other axis), determines which direction we push the originally specified plot area. Options are *left*, *center* (default), and *right* for x axes, and *top*, *middle* (default), and *bottom* for y axes. enumerated /^x([2-9]|[1-9][0-9]+)?$/ info calc If set to another axis id (e.g. `x2`, `y`), the range of this axis will match the range of the corresponding axis in data-coordinates space. Moreover, matching axes share auto-range values, category lists and histogram auto-bins. Note that setting axes simultaneously in both a `scaleanchor` and a `matches` constraint is currently forbidden. Moreover, note that matching axes must have the same `type`. enumerated auto info ticks Sets the tick mode for this axis. If *auto*, the number of ticks is set via `nticks`. If *linear*, the placement of the ticks is determined by a starting position `tick0` and a tick step `dtick` (*linear* is the default value if `tick0` and `dtick` are provided). If *array*, the placement of the ticks is set via `tickvals` and the tick text is `ticktext`. (*array* is the default value if `tickvals` is provided). integer 0 0 style ticks Specifies the maximum number of ticks for the particular axis. The actual number of ticks will be chosen automatically to be less than or equal to `nticks`. Has an effect only if `tickmode` is set to *auto*. any style ticks linear Sets the placement of the first tick on this axis. Use with `dtick`. If the axis `type` is *log*, then you must take the log of your starting tick (e.g. to set the starting tick to 100, set the `tick0` to 2) except when `dtick`=*L<f>* (see `dtick` for more info). If the axis `type` is *date*, it should be a date string, like date data. If the axis `type` is *category*, it should be a number, using the scale where each category is assigned a serial number from zero in the order it appears. any style ticks linear Sets the step in-between ticks on this axis. Use with `tick0`. Must be a positive number, or special strings available to *log* and *date* axes. If the axis `type` is *log*, then ticks are set every 10^(n*dtick) where n is the tick number. For example, to set a tick mark at 1, 10, 100, 1000, ... set dtick to 1. To set tick marks at 1, 100, 10000, ... set dtick to 2. To set tick marks at 1, 5, 25, 125, 625, 3125, ... set dtick to log_10(5), or 0.69897000433. *log* has several special values; *L<f>*, where `f` is a positive number, gives ticks linearly spaced in value (but not position). For example `tick0` = 0.1, `dtick` = *L0.5* will put ticks at 0.1, 0.6, 1.1, 1.6 etc. To show powers of 10 plus small digits between, use *D1* (all digits) or *D2* (only 2 and 5). `tick0` is ignored for *D1* and *D2*. If the axis `type` is *date*, then you must convert the time to milliseconds. For example, to set the interval between ticks to one day, set `dtick` to 86400000.0. *date* also has special values *M<n>* gives ticks spaced by a number of months. `n` must be a positive integer. To set ticks on the 15th of every third month, set `tick0` to *2000-01-15* and `dtick` to *M3*. To set ticks every 4 years, set `dtick` to *M48* data_array ticks Sets the values at which ticks on this axis appear. Only has an effect if `tickmode` is set to *array*. Used with `ticktext`. data data_array ticks Sets the text displayed at the ticks position via `tickvals`. Only has an effect if `tickmode` is set to *array*. Used with `tickvals`. data enumerated outside style ticks Determines whether ticks are drawn or not. If **, this axis' ticks are not drawn. If *outside* (*inside*), this axis' are drawn outside (inside) the axis lines. enumerated labels info labels ticks Determines where ticks and grid lines are drawn with respect to their corresponding tick labels. Only has an effect for axes of `type` *category* or *multicategory*. When set to *boundaries*, ticks and grid lines are drawn half a category to the left/bottom of labels. enumerated TRUE FALSE style ticks+layoutstyle Determines if the axis lines or/and ticks are mirrored to the opposite side of the plotting area. If *true*, the axis lines are mirrored. If *ticks*, the axis lines and ticks are mirrored. If *false*, mirroring is disable. If *all*, axis lines are mirrored on all shared-axes subplots. If *allticks*, axis lines and ticks are mirrored on all shared-axes subplots. number 0 5 style ticks Sets the tick length (in px). number 0 1 style ticks Sets the tick width (in px). color #444 style ticks Sets the tick color. boolean TRUE style ticks Determines whether or not the tick labels are drawn. boolean FALSE style ticks Determines whether long tick labels automatically grow the figure margins. boolean FALSE style modebar Determines whether or not spikes (aka droplines) are drawn for this axis. Note: This only takes affect when hovermode = closest color style none Sets the spike color. If undefined, will use the series color number 3 style none Sets the width (in px) of the zero line. string solid dash style none Sets the dash style of lines. Set to a dash type string (*solid*, *dot*, *dash*, *longdash*, *dashdot*, or *longdashdot*) or a dash length list in px (eg *5px,10px,2px,2px*). flaglist toaxis style toaxis none Determines the drawing mode for the spike line If *toaxis*, the line is drawn from the data point to the axis the series is plotted on. If *across*, the line is drawn across the entire plot area, and supercedes *toaxis*. If *marker*, then a marker dot is drawn on the axis the series is plotted on enumerated data data style none Determines whether spikelines are stuck to the cursor or to the closest datapoints. string style TRUE TRUE ticks HTML font family - the typeface that will be applied by the web browser. The web browser will only be able to apply a font if it is available on the system which it operates. Provide multiple font families, separated by commas, to indicate the preference in which to apply fonts if they aren't available on the system. The plotly service (at https://plot.ly or on-premise) generates images on a server, where only a select number of fonts are installed and supported. These include *Arial*, *Balto*, *Courier New*, *Droid Sans*,, *Droid Serif*, *Droid Sans Mono*, *Gravitas One*, *Old Standard TT*, *Open Sans*, *Overpass*, *PT Sans Narrow*, *Raleway*, *Times New Roman*. number style 1 ticks color style ticks ticks Sets the tick font. object angle auto style ticks Sets the angle of the tick labels with respect to the horizontal. For example, a `tickangle` of -90 draws the tick labels vertically. string style ticks Sets a tick label prefix. enumerated all all style ticks If *all*, all tick labels are displayed with a prefix. If *first*, only the first tick is displayed with a prefix. If *last*, only the last tick is displayed with a suffix. If *none*, tick prefixes are hidden. string style ticks Sets a tick label suffix. enumerated all all style ticks Same as `showtickprefix` but for tick suffixes. enumerated all all style ticks If *all*, all exponents are shown besides their significands. If *first*, only the exponent of the first tick is shown. If *last*, only the exponent of the last tick is shown. If *none*, no exponents appear. enumerated none B style ticks Determines a formatting rule for the tick exponents. For example, consider the number 1,000,000,000. If *none*, it appears as 1,000,000,000. If *e*, 1e+9. If *E*, 1E+9. If *power*, 1x10^9 (with 9 in a super script). If *SI*, 1G. If *B*, 1B. boolean FALSE style ticks If "true", even 4-digit integers are separated string style ticks Sets the tick label formatting rule using d3 formatting mini-languages which are very similar to those in Python. For numbers, see: https://github.com/d3/d3-format/blob/master/README.md#locale_format And for dates see: https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format/blob/master/README.md#locale_format We add one item to d3's date formatter: *%{n}f* for fractional seconds with n digits. For example, *2016-10-13 09:15:23.456* with tickformat *%H~%M~%S.%2f* would display *09~15~23.46* boolean info TRUE ticks Determines whether or not this stop is used. If `false`, this stop is ignored even within its `dtickrange`. info_array info any ticks ticks range [*min*, *max*], where *min*, *max* - dtick values which describe some zoom level, it is possible to omit *min* or *max* value by passing *null* string style ticks string - dtickformat for described zoom level, the same as *tickformat* ticks string style none When used in a template, named items are created in the output figure in addition to any items the figure already has in this array. You can modify these items in the output figure by making your own item with `templateitemname` matching this `name` alongside your modifications (including `visible: false` or `enabled: false` to hide it). Has no effect outside of a template. string info calc Used to refer to a named item in this array in the template. Named items from the template will be created even without a matching item in the input figure, but you can modify one by making an item with `templateitemname` matching its `name`, alongside your modifications (including `visible: false` or `enabled: false` to hide it). If there is no template or no matching item, this item will be hidden unless you explicitly show it with `visible: true`. object object string style none Sets the hover text formatting rule using d3 formatting mini-languages which are very similar to those in Python. For numbers, see: https://github.com/d3/d3-format/blob/master/README.md#locale_format And for dates see: https://github.com/d3/d3-time-format/blob/master/README.md#locale_format We add one item to d3's date formatter: *%{n}f* for fractional seconds with n digits. For example, *2016-10-13 09:15:23.456* with tickformat *%H~%M~%S.%2f* would display *09~15~23.46* boolean FALSE style ticks+layoutstyle Determines whether or not a line bounding this axis is drawn. color #444 style layoutstyle Sets the axis line color. number 0 1 style ticks+layoutstyle Sets the width (in px) of the axis line. boolean style ticks Determines whether or not grid lines are drawn. If *true*, the grid lines are drawn at every tick mark. color #eee style ticks Sets the color of the grid lines. number 0 1 style ticks Sets the width (in px) of the grid lines. boolean style ticks Determines whether or not a line is drawn at along the 0 value of this axis. If *true*, the zero line is drawn on top of the grid lines. color #444 style ticks Sets the line color of the zero line. number 1 style ticks Sets the width (in px) of the zero line. boolean TRUE style ticks Determines whether or not a dividers are drawn between the category levels of this axis. Only has an effect on *multicategory* axes. color #444 style ticks Sets the color of the dividers Only has an effect on *multicategory* axes. number 1 style ticks Sets the width (in px) of the dividers Only has an effect on *multicategory* axes. enumerated free info plot If set to an opposite-letter axis id (e.g. `x2`, `y`), this axis is bound to the corresponding opposite-letter axis. If set to *free*, this axis' position is determined by `position`. enumerated top info plot Determines whether a x (y) axis is positioned at the *bottom* (*left*) or *top* (*right*) of the plotting area. enumerated free info plot If set a same-letter axis id, this axis is overlaid on top of the corresponding same-letter axis, with traces and axes visible for both axes. If *false*, this axis does not overlay any same-letter axes. In this case, for axes with overlapping domains only the highest-numbered axis will be visible. enumerated above traces above traces info plot Sets the layer on which this axis is displayed. If *above traces*, this axis is displayed above all the subplot's traces If *below traces*, this axis is displayed below all the subplot's traces, but above the grid lines. Useful when used together with scatter-like traces with `cliponaxis` set to *false* to show markers and/or text nodes above this axis. info_array info number 0 1 plot 0 plot Sets the domain of this axis (in plot fraction). number 0 1 0 style plot Sets the position of this axis in the plotting space (in normalized coordinates). Only has an effect if `anchor` is set to *free*. enumerated trace trace info calc Specifies the ordering logic for the case of categorical variables. By default, plotly uses *trace*, which specifies the order that is present in the data supplied. Set `categoryorder` to *category ascending* or *category descending* if order should be determined by the alphanumerical order of the category names. Set `categoryorder` to *array* to derive the ordering from the attribute `categoryarray`. If a category is not found in the `categoryarray` array, the sorting behavior for that attribute will be identical to the *trace* mode. The unspecified categories will follow the categories in `categoryarray`. data_array data calc Sets the order in which categories on this axis appear. Only has an effect if `categoryorder` is set to *array*. Used with `categoryorder`. any info none Controls persistence of user-driven changes in axis `range`, `autorange`, and `title` if in `editable: true` configuration. Defaults to `layout.uirevision`. calc boolean info ticks Obsolete. Set `tickmode` to *auto* for old `autotick` *true* behavior. Set `tickmode` to *linear* for `autotick` *false*. string info ticks Value of `title` is no longer a simple *string* but a set of sub-attributes. To set the axis' title, please use `title.text` now. string style TRUE TRUE ticks HTML font family - the typeface that will be applied by the web browser. The web browser will only be able to apply a font if it is available on the system which it operates. Provide multiple font families, separated by commas, to indicate the preference in which to apply fonts if they aren't available on the system. The plotly service (at https://plot.ly or on-premise) generates images on a server, where only a select number of fonts are installed and supported. These include *Arial*, *Balto*, *Courier New*, *Droid Sans*,, *Droid Serif*, *Droid Sans Mono*, *Gravitas One*, *Old Standard TT*, *Open Sans*, *Overpass*, *PT Sans Narrow*, *Raleway*, *Times New Roman*. number style 1 ticks color style ticks ticks Former `titlefont` is now the sub-attribute `font` of `title`. To customize title font properties, please use `title.font` now. color #fff style plot Sets the background color of the range slider. color #444 style plot Sets the border color of the range slider. integer 0 0 style plot Sets the border width of the range slider. boolean TRUE style calc Determines whether or not the range slider range is computed in relation to the input data. If `range` is provided, then `autorange` is set to *false*. info_array info any calc FALSE calc FALSE Sets the range of the range slider. If not set, defaults to the full xaxis range. If the axis `type` is *log*, then you must take the log of your desired range. If the axis `type` is *date*, it should be date strings, like date data, though Date objects and unix milliseconds will be accepted and converted to strings. If the axis `type` is *category*, it should be numbers, using the scale where each category is assigned a serial number from zero in the order it appears. number 0.15 0 1 style plot The height of the range slider as a fraction of the total plot area height. boolean TRUE info calc Determines whether or not the range slider will be visible. If visible, perpendicular axes will be set to `fixedrange` calc TRUE enumerated auto match style calc Determines whether or not the range of this axis in the rangeslider use the same value than in the main plot when zooming in/out. If *auto*, the autorange will be used. If *fixed*, the `range` is used. If *match*, the current range of the corresponding y-axis on the main subplot is used. info_array style any plot plot Sets the range of this axis for the rangeslider. calc object object boolean info plot Determines whether or not this range selector is visible. Note that range selectors are only available for x axes of `type` set to or auto-typed to *date*. boolean info TRUE plot Determines whether or not this button is visible. enumerated info month month plot The unit of measurement that the `count` value will set the range by. enumerated info backward backward plot Sets the range update mode. If *backward*, the range update shifts the start of range back *count* times *step* milliseconds. If *todate*, the range update shifts the start of range back to the first timestamp from *count* times *step* milliseconds back. For example, with `step` set to *year* and `count` set to *1* the range update shifts the start of the range back to January 01 of the current year. Month and year *todate* are currently available only for the built-in (Gregorian) calendar. number info 0 1 plot Sets the number of steps to take to update the range. Use with `step` to specify the update interval. string info plot Sets the text label to appear on the button. plot Sets the specifications for each buttons. By default, a range selector comes with no buttons. string style none When used in a template, named items are created in the output figure in addition to any items the figure already has in this array. You can modify these items in the output figure by making your own item with `templateitemname` matching this `name` alongside your modifications (including `visible: false` or `enabled: false` to hide it). Has no effect outside of a template. string info calc Used to refer to a named item in this array in the template. Named items from the template will be created even without a matching item in the input figure, but you can modify one by making an item with `templateitemname` matching its `name`, alongside your modifications (including `visible: false` or `enabled: false` to hide it). If there is no template or no matching item, this item will be hidden unless you explicitly show it with `visible: true`. object object number -2 3 style plot Sets the x position (in normalized coordinates) of the range selector. enumerated auto left info plot Sets the range selector's horizontal position anchor. This anchor binds the `x` position to the *left*, *center* or *right* of the range selector. number -2 3 style plot Sets the y position (in normalized coordinates) of the range selector. enumerated auto bottom info plot Sets the range selector's vertical position anchor This anchor binds the `y` position to the *top*, *middle* or *bottom* of the range selector. string style TRUE TRUE plot HTML font family - the typeface that will be applied by the web browser. The web browser will only be able to apply a font if it is available on the system which it operates. Provide multiple font families, separated by commas, to indicate the preference in which to apply fonts if they aren't available on the system. The plotly service (at https://plot.ly or on-premise) generates images on a server, where only a select number of fonts are installed and supported. These include *Arial*, *Balto*, *Courier New*, *Droid Sans*,, *Droid Serif*, *Droid Sans Mono*, *Gravitas One*, *Old Standard TT*, *Open Sans*, *Overpass*, *PT Sans Narrow*, *Raleway*, *Times New Roman*. number style 1 plot color style plot plot Sets the font of the range selector button text. object color #eee style plot Sets the background color of the range selector buttons. color style plot Sets the background color of the active range selector button. color #444 style plot Sets the color of the border enclosing the range selector. number 0 0 style plot Sets the width (in px) of the border enclosing the range selector. plot object enumerated gregorian info calc gregorian Sets the calendar system to use for `range` and `tick0` if this is a date axis. This does not set the calendar for interpreting data on this axis, that's specified in the trace or via the global `layout.calendar` TRUE object string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for tickvals . none string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for ticktext . none string info Sets the source reference on plot.ly for categoryarray . none boolean info plot A single toggle to hide the axis while preserving interaction like dragging. Default is true when a cheater plot is present on the axis, otherwise false color #444 style ticks Sets default for all colors associated with this axis all at once: line, font, tick, and grid colors. Grid color is lightened by blending this with the plot background Individual pieces can override this. string info ticks Sets the title of this axis. Note that before the existence of `title.text`, the title's contents used to be defined as the `title` attribute itself. This behavior has been deprecated. string style TRUE TRUE ticks HTML font family - the typeface that will be applied by the web browser. The web browser will only be able to apply a font if it is available on the system which it operates. Provide multiple font families, separated by commas, to indicate the preference in which to apply fonts if they aren't available on the system. The plotly service (at https://plot.ly or on-premise) generates images on a server, where only a select number of fonts are installed and supported. These include *Arial*, *Balto*, *Courier New*, *Droid Sans*,, *Droid Serif*, *Droid Sans Mono*, *Gravitas One*, *Old Standard TT*, *Open Sans*, *Overpass*, *PT Sans Narrow*, *Raleway*, *Times New Roman*. number style 1 ticks color style ticks ticks Sets this axis' title font. Note that the title's font used to be customized by the now deprecated `titlefont` attribute. object ticks object enumerated - - info calc TRUE Sets the axis type. By default, plotly attempts to determined the axis type by looking into the data of the traces that referenced the axis in question. enumerated TRUE TRUE info axrange Determines whether or not the range of this axis is computed in relation to the input data. See `rangemode` for more info. If `range` is provided, then `autorange` is set to *false*. enumerated normal normal info plot If *normal*, the range is computed in relation to the extrema of the input data. If *tozero*`, the range extends to 0, regardless of the input data If *nonnegative*, the range is non-negative, regardless of the input data. Applies only to linear axes. info_array info any axrange FALSE TRUE axrange FALSE TRUE Sets the range of this axis. If the axis `type` is *log*, then you must take the log of your desired range (e.g. to set the range from 1 to 100, set the range from 0 to 2). If the axis `type` is *date*, it should be date strings, like date data, though Date objects and unix milliseconds will be accepted and converted to strings. If the axis `type` is *category*, it should be numbers, using the scale where each category is assigned a serial number from zero in the order it appears. boolean FALSE info calc Determines whether or not this axis is zoom-able. If true, then zoom is disabled. enumerated /^x([2-9]|[1-9][0-9]+)?$/ info plot If set to another axis id (e.g. `x2`, `y`), the range of this axis changes together with the range of the corresponding axis such that the scale of pixels per unit is in a constant ratio. Both axes are still zoomable, but when you zoom one, the other will zoom the same amount, keeping a fixed midpoint. `constrain` and `constraintoward` determine how we enforce the constraint. You can chain these, ie `yaxis: {scaleanchor: *x*}, xaxis2: {scaleanchor: *y*}` but you can only link axes of the same `type`. The linked axis can have the opposite letter (to constrain the aspect ratio) or the same letter (to match scales across subplots). Loops (`yaxis: {scaleanchor: *x*}, xaxis: {scaleanchor: *y*}` or longer) are redundant and the last constraint encountered will be ignored to avoid possible inconsistent constraints via `scaleratio`. Note that setting axes simultaneously in both a `scaleanchor` and a `matches` constraint is currently forbidden. number 0 1 info plot If this axis is linked to another by `scaleanchor`, this determines the pixel to unit scale ratio. For example, if this value is 10, then every unit on this axis spans 10 times the number of pixels as a unit on the linked axis.
